transcripts.text: Rana, it's a great pleasure to meet you finally personally, having read and greatly admired you from having read your book and early draft of your book, Women Are Not Allowed to Dream.  Coming from Saudi Arabia, I have the impression that unless you're rich and male, Saudi Arabia is not a very nice place to live.  Is that a fair point?

Yeah, like a woman and also like FAS is like the most worst place to live for women.  We don't have any dream there.  We all that time and depended about our family, my father, my brother, my husband.  It's like I can't do anything in this country.  I need all that time, the permission from them.  And even if my situation is really bad, if I get hit or if I have like something bad with my family, I can't call the police or ask for help.
Yes.  And when you were not allowed to dream, what dreams did you actually have?  Did you dream to come to a free country?

Yeah, to live in a free country, to have my freedom life, to be an atheist and not to behave like I am a Muslim but from inside I am an atheist, to respect me.  I don't want to believe in any kind of religion or God.  I want to live like in peace without any forcing to be someone else and to study nuclear physics to meet you and yeah.
Is it right to say that you didn't really know that there was such a thing as an atheist, that it was possible to be an atheist when you were growing up?

I was completely shocked when I saw the word atheist in English.  I took it to Google and I translated it to Arabic and even in Arabic language what does mean?  And then I searched and then I was completely shocked.  There is people in our life, they don't believe in God or they don't have any religion.  It's like something so huge for me.
It was impossible to believe that anybody could not believe in God.

And from this moment I started to search, and in Arabic Twitter or Facebook or media, if you start to search about atheists, the first book they put it, you have to read it, it's your book, God's Delusion.
And you read that in Arabic?

I read it in Arabic.  It was like it's illegal to have it, even to download it.  I have to change my VPN and I make like strip to get the book.  And when I get the book, I download it in my laptop and then I put it in my flash memory.  And I keep my flash memory like drugs or something really dangerous.  And when I read it in my room, I close the door.  I bought something from the door and I open my laptop and I start to read, read, read.
What would have happened to you if you'd been caught reading it?

My family is really strict with religion.  Because the name in Arabic, God illusion, if someone sees it from my family, they think I will be like hit and they take all my contact laptop, handy or anything like from this and I will be obsolete in the house and I will not allow to go out or to contact anyone until they be sure that I am Muslim and I don't have any other idea.
And do you still feel threatened even living in Germany?

Yeah, I'm threatened because I talk about freedom of religion and I talk about human rights.  It's coming from the people that are living here in Germany.  They are also refugees.  They come from the other country.  Yeah.
So you are being threatened by fellow refugees who have come out of Islamic countries and they come to a free country, Germany, and they still threaten you?
Yeah.  Because I talk about this topic in Arabic language and other language and I am really like support women to be free also, not only because of the religion.
So these refugees in Germany who threaten you, do they not realize they're now living in a free country?

I think they don't want to realize that.  They want to stay in the same idea.  Why don't they go back home now?  That's not my decision.  I hope they will be really struck with this kind of people.  When I see people, they threat the other and they are dangerous and they don't respect the freedom.  They don't respect the right here.  Why they are here?
Do your family know where you are?
They know that I am in Germany, but they don't know which city.
So do you keep that secret?
Yeah, also I block my information with the help with police and the immigration office here.  So anyone who take my name and try to find where I live, he can't.
And what would happen to you if they did find where you are?
Before three or two weeks, I get information that my brother tried to find someone by dark net to kill me here in Germany.  To kill you?  Yeah.
Your brother, your own brother would kill you?
My own brother.  It was like, I was completely sad.  I was crying when I go to the police.
I'm not surprised.
Yeah, and I make like complaint and I see his name in the beginning like really like a criminal and this like... So much, it was so feel for me.
Did you love your brother when you were in Saudi Arabia?

Yeah, before I become an atheist and before everything in my mind change, we was really close, sister and brother.  We was talking, getting to restaurant, doing like something together, but after I move and after I start my life here, he not accept that, I bring the shame for the family.  That is incredibly sad.

Yeah.  And it's really troubling that a belief, a religious belief can actually take over somebody's mind, can parasitize somebody's mind to the extent that he would want to kill his own beloved sister.  That is deeply disturbing and it just shows the power, the evil power that religion can exert over a vulnerable human mind.  I'm shocked by that.  And I'm very sorry for you, but I greatly admire your courage, the courage with which you are standing up to this.
Yeah.  Thank you.

And French.
And French.  It's German and French.  Not in Arabic.
Not in Arabic, yeah.
Not English.
Not English.

you know if there is like publisher house they get interesting about my story.  they contact me or contact my agent or contact my publisher house in Germany and we start to deal with that.

I think a lot, but we can't really be sure because they can't show them identity or they can't say we are as they are.  I think I can say like three, four millions.  We can say less.

Well, we know, don't we, that the Arabic translation of the God Delusion, which you read, you downloaded, has been downloaded, I think, 13 million times, the Arabic translation, and I think 3 million of those in Saudi Arabia, which is a very significant... figure, which does suggest something very encouraging.
